commander.name: Major-General Iven Mackay
commander.previous_service: Commanded 6th Division from formation through North Africa, Greece, and Crete campaigns
commander.note: Mackay served until 14 August 1941 when replaced by Major-General E.F. Herring

command.headquarters_location: Palestine/Syria (reconstituting after Greece/Crete, garrison duties in Syria)

tanks.note: Australian infantry divisions had no organic tank units. Tank support provided by British armoured brigades when needed.

Universal Carrier (Bren Gun Carrier).role: Infantry battalion carrier platoons (21 per battalion, 9 battalions)

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer Mk I.organization: Three field regiments (2/1st, 2/2nd, 2/3rd), each with 24 guns in three batteries of 8 guns
Ordnance QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer Mk I.note: Re-equipped with 25-pounders in 1940, replacing 18-pounders from WWI

Ordnance QF 2-pounder Anti-Tank Gun.organization: 2/1st Anti-Tank Regiment, four batteries of 12 guns each
Ordnance QF 2-pounder Anti-Tank Gun.note: Many mounted en portee on 30cwt trucks for mobility in desert

anti_aircraft.note: Light AA regiment authorized but not fully equipped by Q3 1941. AA defense provided by attached British units.

reconnaissance.note: Air support provided by RAF Desert Air Force units, not organic to division

supply_status.note: Division reconstituting after heavy losses in Greece and Crete. Supply situation improved by Q3 1941 in Syria garrison role.

subordinate_units.note: First brigade to see action at Bardia, January 1941
Fought in Greece and Crete, depleted elements in Syria Q3 1941
Formed 1940 when division reorganized to three-battalion brigades. In Syria garrison Q3 1941
Raised October 1939, Victoria personnel. Lost equipment in Greece, re-equipped
Reformed late 1940, many guns on portee mounts
Divisional reconnaissance unit, later became commando unit
Combat engineers for construction, demolition, mine warfare
Construction, defense works, fought as infantry in Syria-Lebanon campaign
Provost company, postal unit, employment company, workshops, AASC transport companies

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry Division - all-arms combined operations with British armor support when needed
special_capabilities: Experienced in desert warfare from North Africa campaigns
Amphibious operations experience from Greece and Crete
Mountain warfare capability from Greece campaign
High morale and esprit de corps despite heavy losses
tactical_innovations: Effective use of 2-pounder anti-tank guns en portee for mobility
Integration of Universal Carriers at battalion level for fire support
Experienced in fighting under air superiority disadvantage
known_issues: Division significantly under strength in Q3 1941 after Greece and Crete losses
Many replacements were less experienced than original volunteers
Equipment losses from Greece requiring re-equipment
No organic tank units - dependent on British armor for support
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive North Africa experience led to adaptations in water discipline, vehicle maintenance, navigation, and use of portee AT guns

special_rules: Commonwealth Volunteers: +1 morale in defensive positions
Desert Veterans: Ignore first movement penalty in desert terrain
Experienced Leaders: Battalion and brigade commanders may re-roll one failed command check per game
Depleted Strength: In Q3 1941 scenarios, reduce battalion strength by 10-15% to reflect losses
historical_engagements: Battle of Beda Fomm (support role, February 1941)
Greece Campaign (March-April 1941) - Vevi, Klidi Pass, Tempe Gorge

historical_notes.formation: The 6th Division was the first Australian division raised for WWII, formed September 1939 as part of the 2nd Australian Imperial Force (2nd AIF). Initially had four-battalion brigades (16th, 17th, 18th) but reorganized to British three-battalion brigades when 18th Brigade sent to UK, with 19th Brigade formed as replacement.
historical_notes.q3_1941_status: In Q3 1941 (July-September), the 6th Division was reconstituting in Palestine and Syria after suffering heavy casualties in the Greece and Crete campaigns. The division was significantly under strength, with many units at 70-80% of establishment. Commander Iven Mackay was replaced by Major-General E.F. Herring on 14 August 1941. The 19th Brigade and elements of other brigades were on garrison duty in Syria following the successful Syria-Lebanon Campaign against Vichy French forces. The division would remain in the Middle East until early 1942 when recalled to Australia after Pearl Harbor.
historical_notes.combat_record: First Australian unit to see combat in WWII. Highly successful in Operation Compass in North Africa (January 1941), capturing Bardia and Tobruk. Fought in Greece (March-April 1941) where defeated by German forces. Evacuated to Crete where again defeated in May 1941 with heavy losses. Participated in Syria-Lebanon Campaign (June-July 1941) defeating Vichy French forces. Total casualties through mid-1941: approximately 5,500 killed, wounded, and captured.
historical_notes.equipment_status: Division re-equipped with 25-pounder field guns in 1940 (replacing WWI-era 18-pounders). Lost significant equipment in Greece evacuation, re-equipped in Egypt/Palestine. By Q3 1941, most equipment restored to reasonable levels but some units still below establishment. Universal Carriers being received in increasing numbers (21 per battalion authorized).
historical_notes.personnel_quality: Original volunteers were highly motivated and well-trained. After heavy losses in Greece and Crete, division received replacements who were less experienced. However, surviving cadre of experienced NCOs and officers maintained high standards. Australian troops highly regarded by British commanders for initiative, fighting spirit, and offensive capability.

source: Tier 1: British Army Lists (July 1941, October 1941) - Limited detail, confirmed Australian units present (Confidence: 90%)
Tier 2: Australian War Memorial online collections and histories (Confidence: 85%)
Tier 2: Military history websites (Military Wiki, History Guild) for unit structures (Confidence: 80%)
Tier 3: General web search for organizational details and equipment (Confidence: 75%)
Historical context: Multiple published sources on 6th Division operations 1940-1941 (Confidence: 85%)
known_gaps: Exact commander names for most subordinate units (brigade, regiment, battalion commanders) - sources did not provide Q3 1941 specific names
Precise personnel numbers by unit - calculated from establishment tables and historical strength estimates
Exact operational vehicle counts - estimated from typical divisional establishments
Specific serial numbers of equipment variants - general types confirmed but detailed variants uncertain
Chief of Staff name for division headquarters
Detailed ammunition and supply stockpile numbers - estimated from typical divisional parameters
validation.methodology: Division-level data compiled from multiple web sources. Personnel strength based on historical records showing ~16,000 total after reorganization and losses. Equipment allocations based on Australian infantry division establishment tables from 1941 period. Infantry battalion strength: 9 battalions × ~900 men = 8,100 infantry. Artillery: 3 field regiments × 600 = 1,800. Engineers, signals, medical, support: ~3,200. HQ and divisional troops: ~2,900. Bottom-up aggregation not performed from individual subordinate unit TO&Es (those not yet created).
